newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft planning simpler computer - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft planning simpler computer - WSJ.

text.p: Microsoft Corp is gathering up its industry allies to propose a simpler, less expensive personal computer in order to counter a threat from a new kind of network computer, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.
The newspaper quoted people familiar with the matter as saying Microsoft had been defining its proposed computer -- and even its name -- this week.
The company was expected to present its proposal on Monday at a meeting of World Wide Web developers that it was hosting in San Jose, Calif, it said.

The newspaper said some of the initiative's supporters included Intel Corp, Hewlett-Packard Co, Compaq Computer Corp, Dell Computer Corp and other makers of personal computers that use Microsoft's Windows operating system and Intel microchips.

The new network computers don't have a disk drive and retrieve their software from the Internet and other computer networks, it said. The method gives their users a cost advantage over the traditional personal computers where Microsoft and Intel technology dominate, it added.

On Tuesday, Sun Microsystems Inc is scheduled to launch its version of such a computer called JavaStation, a desktop machine that will cost less than $1,000 and have a different kind of operating system.
